body:
In #189 people are already moaning about the magic "compile libuv" scripts we're shipping and proposing solutions which all effectively move the deck chairs around but don't steer the ship.

Should neovim try to provide magic scripts which either fetch dependencies or compile those bundled with the source? Or should we instead provide guidance in the per-platform build instructions on how to fetch and compile (when necessary) the dependencies? (Like we currently do for, e.g., cmake itself.)

My personal view is that people building neovim from source should have the knowledge to fetch and build the correct libuv from source too and packagers of neovim will just be ignoring the bundled libuv.

Feel free to add comments below. Should @tarruda decide that people can build libuv themselves (or install the appropriate system packages), I'll propose a PR removing all the dependency fetching stuff. Should @tarruda want to keep on with the possibility to compile the world from the neovim top-level make, I would advocate keeping the current subtree approach since I believe it is superior to other solutions.

comment_data.body:
No, you should not take responsibility at all for system libs.  It's not your job whatsoever.  All you must do is provide an INSTALL file which lists necessary dependencies.

If neovim doesn't build against the latest stable release of those libraries, that is a bug.

Any other solution will lead to madness.
I agree with Earnestly.
+1 @Earnestly
+1 @Earnestly

The only reason I see for bundling or automatically fetching dependencies would be libraries the Neovim project forked to add new features that will not make it into upstream. Everything else should be the duty of distribution packagers. Add clear install instructions and a list of dependencies needed and they should be good to go.
:+1: to @Earnestly's proposed solution of an `INSTALL` file although I may have used more circumspect language to recommend it :).
@wasamasa Yep, but then fetching+patching would be the best (instead of holding the entire library). This also allows us to easily send our patches back to the upstream projects.
:+1: @Earnestly

> Should @tarruda decide that people can build libuv themselves (or install the appropriate system packages), I'll propose a PR removing all the dependency fetching stuff. 

The PR would, of course, add appropriate runes to `.travis.yml` to get libuv installed as a `before_script` step.

Didn't #116 fixed this problem by checking for system libuv? Also #99 bundled libuv as a git subtree, so the download scripts are no longer necessary(Maybe we still need to remove the functions). In my head, those two changes should make everyone happy, so what would exactly be gained from this PR?

> If neovim doesn't build against the latest stable release of those libraries, that is a bug.
> 
> Any other solution will lead to madness.

Why targeting a specific version would be a bug? [NPM](http://npmjs.org/) lets programmers publish modules targeting a specific dependency versions. If two modules have the same dependencies of different versions it simply installs the required dependency version for each module. This scheme works extremely well, node.js programs never have problems with dependencies.

And why would the current solution lead to madness? Can you explain or give examples?

> If neovim doesn't build against the latest stable release of those libraries, that is a bug.

I think that's a bit strong.  It can take time to bring a code base up-to-date--especially if they have breaking or incompatible changes.  Perhaps the project's strongest motivation is not to work with the latest stable of libuv, but something else important to the project--like integrating luajit.

I think it would be ideal if we could keep up-to-date, just not so convinced that it's a "bug" if the project decides that other matters are more important than compiling with the latest dependency.  You need some freedom in there to take on upgrading dependencies when the project is ready.

And FWIW, I believe we need to give @tarruda some room to fulfill his obligations.  Changing things out from under his feet every step of the way does nothing but impede him.  I'm glad everyone is enthusiastic and wants to help (me included!), but there's something to be said for pinning some things down while things get built up.

And to comment more directly on the issue: I think we should document the dependencies, and let developers get them in place.  I don't think NeoVim should be responsible for building them.

> Didn't #116 fixed this problem by checking for system libuv?

@tarruda It allowed compilation with system libuv but didn't remove the 'compile bundled libuv by default' behaviour which would result from following the build instructions in the README.

This issue is about whether the `third-party/libuv` and `scripts/` directories should go away to be replaced with an `INSTALL` file containing something like "ensure cmake, xxx, yyy, and libuv version blah, blah are installed" in it. After that the top-level `Makefile` might as well go away too.

A starting point for the `INSTALL` file would probably be the build instructions currently in the `README.md` file.

> And FWIW, I believe we need to give @tarruda some room to fulfill his obligations. Changing things out from under his feet every step of the way does nothing but impede him. 

:+1: to this. That's why I'll happily deal with whatever @tarruda decides. I just want to settle the matter in one place rather than in a thousand comments on a thousand rejected pull requests ;).

(And, speaking as the person who is triaging said requests, it is far easier and fairer to respond with "thanks, but see #194" and then close if need be rather than having the same argument each time.)
@tarruda OK, thanks. I'll prepare a PR.

Personally, I prefer that neovim bundles libuv.

Consider Node.js as a counterexample. I love how I can simply download Node.js source code and compile it right away. That's because [most dependencies are part of the software configuration](https://github.com/joyent/node/tree/master/deps), and there does not seem to be any madness, as far as I know.

I also think that by doing that, it would make the neovim core much more stable, and behaviors much more predictable.

However, I agree that there is an option to use the installed libuv.

Right, I've added #198 which should address this issue by making the use of system-supplied dependencies the default option. The bundled libuv sources are still there and if anyone complains we can all fail to check our privilege and assert that bandwidth is cheap ;).

>  The bundled libuv sources are still there and if anyone complains we can all fail to check our privilege and assert that bandwidth is cheap ;).

Not to belabour the point, but check your privilege.

Even if bandwidth (and the added time due to all future clones being bloated) is cheap, it doesn't change the fact that having those libraries tracked by our git is a textbook anti-pattern and a clear mistake. That should really go. I don't see any good reason to include them at all, let alone in their entirety, without making use of git's submodule support (which would be a more reasonable method of including these libraries).

> I don't see any good reason to include them at all, let alone in their entirety, without making use of git's submodule support (which would be a more reasonable method of including these libraries).

We currently use git's subtree support which is usually considered to be a better solution than submodules. It provides the same ability to embed a specific commit but does not require the cloning of the entire submodule history.

Note that the third-party directory isn't managed by `cp` which the advocates of submodules would appear to be assuming.

I personally agree that removing the third-party directory would be desirable for many reasons but, for the moment, the result of this discussion was to keep it.

> We currently use git's subtree support **which is usually considered to be a better solution than submodules.**

I think that is a big point of contention.

> I personally agree that removing the third-party directory would be desirable for many reasons but, **for the moment, the result of this discussion was to keep it.**

I would like to move for a reopening of the discussion, then, as there are plenty of developers who do not feel as though the case has been conclusively made, and this issue has not insignificant consequences for the repository.

> I think that is a big point of contention.

I agree that the opinion is not universally held but the voices shouting the praises of submodules over subtree are undoubtedly fewer than those shouting the reverse. In any case, this is not the right place to argue subtree vs. submodule since it's somewhat orthogonal to the issue of whether third-party should be there at all. Suffice it to say that the third-party directory is not simply untarring the latest libuv release all over the source tree which is clearly a sub-optimal solution.

> I would like to move for a reopening of the discussion, then, as there are plenty of developers who do not feel as though the case has been conclusively made, and this issue has not insignificant consequences for the repository.

I would be happy with that if @tarruda wants to. As it is, I feel I would only be repeating myself if the issue were re-opened and I think I've stated my own position already.
That's fair. Thanks for handling this so well.

I just want to make it as simple as possible for people to contribute. I myself dont like depending on system libraries for development(except for common libraries of course).

Perhaps thats influence from programming in node.js/python which have their own package managers that install things locally to the project. Personally I like the fact that I can quickly setup a development environment without having to mess with the system.

Plus, even if we remove the subtree, the objects are permanently stored in our repository so we might as well make use of it :)

Sorry if this is a an anti-pattern, but I dont think changing this now will have any positive result. When neovim is ready to package we can visit this topic again.

> Sorry if this is a an anti-pattern, but I dont think changing this now will have any positive result. When neovim is ready to package we can visit this topic again. 

You mean when there'll be tons of hacks depending on it? Yeah, it sounds like it will be super easy to fix then! But sure, shoot yourself in foot if you like. It's your fork.

I am still not convinced why bundling the dependencies is a bad idea, but I see a lot of fear...
- It will lead to madness.
- It is a textbook anti-pattern.
- It is a clear mistake.
- You'll shoot yourself in foot.

It may be a bad practice in some circumstance, yes, but obviously, it does not always apply that we should reject it uncritically...

...especially when [several](https://github.com/joyent/node/tree/master/deps) [successful](https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/tree/master/src/qt) [projects](https://github.com/justinlatimer/node-midi/tree/master/src/lib/RtMidi) [have](https://github.com/tmm1/pygments.rb/tree/master/vendor/pygments-main) been doing it without suffering the said consequences. Better to discuss about this more objectively and be more concrete about the consequences.

Here are few reasons to include the dependencies that quickly change in our source tree...
- Ease of installation... [we don't suffer installation problems due to paths](https://github.com/LearnBoost/node-canvas/issues/225). Less burden for users.
- More predictable and stable behavior. We don't have to deal with problems where same version works in some machine but not the other due to different version of dependencies.
- We are in complete control. We can make the software depend on newer dependency that's backward-incompatible without putting the burden on the users to update the dependency.
Note: [homebrew doesn't accept formula that download things.](http://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/wiki/Acceptable-Formulae#wiki-we-dont-like-install-scripts-that-download-things)

title: is it our responsibility to compile dependencies
